Entries.default: Your vantage among the hooded witnesses affords you a view of both the inquisitors and the accused. You recognize the latter as the spirit shackled near the portal above.

"We gather in the sight of Woedica and Wael to thresh truth from falsehood and see justice upheld."

The voice seems to echo from nowhere in particular, though the figures before you present the tableau of a trial in progress.
[Use the broken dagger relic to take on the role of a witness.]
[Use the relic to take on the role of the inquisitor.]
Before you, the elf you saw chained above stands bloodied and shackled, her gaze lowered to the stones.
"She's lying."
"You are mistaken."
[Say nothing.]
"You've been charged with crimes against identity. How do you answer?"
"Free the prisoner. She has committed no crime."
"Let's get this over with. Kill the accused."
"Does the witness have testimony to present?"
"The self and the soul may not be the same, but they can never be at odds."
"A line can't be drawn between the soul and the self."
"How can you possibly know the purpose of her soul?"
"The accused's soul was set to a divine purpose, as was every soul present. "
"In accepting the lie of the self, she abandoned that purpose. She elevated the role above the player."
"Of this charge I bear no guilt. I am naught but myself. How could I be other?"

"What?"

The chained elf's brown eyes widen.

"What?"

The chained elf's brown eyes widen.
"This woman's soul - not her mind - is divided against itself."
"For all of the information it carries, the soul is ultimately a form of energy. It has no volition and no purpose save that we set it to."
"Because they belong to one another. They cannot be sundered without being changed."
"You could be divided against yourself."
"You could be lying about who you are."
"Did I say kill? I meant imprison. For further interrogation."
"A quick death."
"Cut off her ears and flay her skin from her back."
"On second thought..."

"The matter before this tribunal tonight - identity."

The dagger again warms, oozing its thick ichor.
"I've got one of those. Am I in trouble too?"
"I worry this place grows less stable as a result of our actions, and it was not particularly stable to begin with."
[Attack the gathered court.]
"Here we go again."
Your words die on the air, as if spoken into a blanket. None of the gathered apparitions respond to them in any way.
None of the gathered figures respond.
"Just play it like you're about to call a surprise witness. It'll put everyone on edge."
"All of this due process is making me queasy."
"Why can no one simply agree on facts?" TekÄ“hu worries the back of his head and sighs.
"Clan elders sometimes assign impossible ordeals meant to teach humility. These trials feel much the same."
"At least we learn more with each tedious tribunal."
"Ain't but one way to chart a sea, cap, be it of the soul or no. Sailing it."
"This place seems a labyrinth of memories. I suspect that we may be nearing its center."
"You think maybe you can help these souls escape their bonds?"
"We should make haste. I fear if we stay here too long, our souls will be in danger."
"The gods craft each soul to a purpose. They grant it flesh and bone and set it to its task."
"The self is the lie. A lie you whisper to yourself, a lie shouted at you by others. A lie you perform like a role upon a stage with your every action."
"How do you answer these charges?"
"I bear guilt for many things, but in my service to the divine I have never wavered. Never once."
"You bear guilt of the gravest heterodoxy - Your self stands at cross purposes to your soul."
[Attack] "Enough of this sham!"
The other witnesses step away from you as the masked inquisitors turn their eyes towards your outburst.
"The intruders turn arms against this body! Destroy them!"
"Does the witness have testimony to present?"
[Remain silent.]
"You then, in your mask and your robes, you are so much truer."
"There is no shame to be found in the service of the gods. The masks we wear reflect our roles as mere instruments of a divine will."
"The accused sought my assistance in thwarting this tribunal."
"She claimed to me to be a disciple of Iovara."
"Apologies. I have nothing further."
[Say nothing.]
"We admitted you that you might observe the errors of the accused and hence temper your own soul. Further interruption will see you ejected from this hall."
"Don't suppose you considered not flapping your ballast hole, Captain Watcher?"
"I- I've done no such thing!"
Xoti's lips part as if she might interrupt, but she instead falls silent. She puffs out her cheeks above crossed arms.

"How disappointing."

The inquisitors exchange nods before returning their attention to the accused.
The accused raises her face, her broken lip and darkened eyes turned defiantly against her interrogators.
"Let's delay this no longer then! Speak! Speak! What would you do to me? What example would you set?"
The court's many figures erupt in hissing whispers.
"On what do you base this claim?"
"Were such the case, each child born would be the sum of its previous lives."
"On what do you base this claim?"
"Choose your next words carefully, witness."
"Souls exist without the gods. They predate the gods. The gods do not define their purpose."
"The gods grant us soul energy that we might be greater than mere vessels. That we might develop the identity of which you speak. Self is the purpose of the soul."
"What is the soul save essence implanted into a body at birth?"
"Actually... that's a pretty good point."
After a moment of awkward silence, the court refocuses on the accused.
"The self is defined within the mind, a part of the body, but the body is suffused by the soul. They are one and the same."
"Maybe it is. It's just not obvious. I was shaped by my own past life, for example, but I only know it because I Awakened."
"This tribunal did not convene to contemplate matters of metaphysics. Only the fate of the accused is at question."
"Apologies. I have nothing further."

"You would bring words of heresy into this hallowed hall?"

She looks to the gathered witnesses.
"Put him to death."
"Listen, all of you! Your faith is false!"
"There is no graver sin than the betrayal of the soul in service to the self. Thus only the gravest punishment shall suffice."
"You shall be flayed over the course of months, as priests of Abydon preserve your body from death. The skin shall be tanned for use by our scribes."
"When you have been fully harvested, your feet and hands shall be removed, and the stumps cauterized by priests of Magran."
[Say nothing.]
"This is insane!"
"Silence!"
"The gods exist to guide, to teach, to lead, not to inflict pointless cruelties on those who don't meet your standards!"
Your words echo through the chamber. The other figures shimmer, strains of essence from throughout the room coalescing before you into a single pulsing mote of essence.
[Say nothing.]
"This is insane!"
"You shall then crawl to Noonfrost and throw yourself into the White Void. Any encouragement you require shall be provided at the points of heated spears."
"Silence!"
"This- 'tis monstrous. 'Tis an affront to the gods you claim to serve."
"The sentence has been pronounced, and so shall it be carried out. All praise be to the gods."
"None of this is real!"
"How can she answer? What does it even mean?"
Your words echo through the chamber, demanding the attention of all gathered.

"What?"

The chained elf's brown eyes widen.
"Let's not be hasty. Our actions here may result in consequences elsewhere."
"It shall be done... but how?"
"What more could you want to know?"
The accused's head falls as the other gathered figures pray their thanks to Woedica.
"It shall be done!"
The other inquisitors stare wordlessly at you.
"What indeed? Have not I answered your endless queries?"
"Crowd be curdling, cap."
The other inquisitors stare wordlessly at you.
"It's all a dream!"
"This is just a reflection of the memories of a single broken soul."
"We are in Hel, and the only person being judged here is me."
"Listen, all of you! Your faith is false!"
Pallegina sets her jaw as she lets out a long sigh and rolls her eyes.
Aloth sighs through his nose.
Pinching the bridge of her nose, Ydwin sighs.
Maia furrows her brow and sighs through her nose.
The other inquisitors stare wordlessly at you.
"I wonder if your words are truer than you know."
"Yours is false! You've been turned by the heretics!"
"But what of the accused?"
"The gods demand justice!"
"There is no accused. There's no accuser. There's only us."
"The gods were forged by Engwith of its own people's souls in order to control you!"
"The gods want us to lead by example, not force conversion at the point of a blade."
"Oh for - fine! Just kill her, then."
Discontented growls spread among the gathered spirits. Tears, however, line the accused elf's cheeks.
"Heresy!"

"Prettily done, Captain Watcher."

The orlan shakes his head.
"The inquisitor has been turned!"
"The gods exist to guide, to teach, to lead, not to inflict pointless cruelties on those who don't meet your standards!"
"Engwith will fall, and the gods will fight among themselves. All of this is meaningless!"
"Our souls do not control us. They're ours to define. Otherwise we'd be the person we are from birth. We'd never change."
"You don't find it curious that only the accuser and the accused have form here? "
"This place is formed of trauma - the trauma of an experienced torturer torturing herself."
"If you continue to spout such ridiculous madness, you shall be escorted from these halls." Her voice quivers.
"Try it! Ghosts don't frighten me!"
"You're seeking the truth, aren't you? Then don't blind yourself to it."
"It's not madness. You, me, we're the same! Trust me as you would yourself!"
The inquisitor takes a step from you, and beyond her, the accused looks up. Their mouths open in unison, then close again.
The inquisitor looks from you to the accused and back to you again.
Naxiva raises a hand to her mask and rests her fingers there briefly before the scene shimmers and dissolves into a pulsing mote of spirit energy.
Your words echo through the chamber. The other figures shimmer, strains of essence from throughout the room coalescing before you into a single pulsing mote of essence.
"The gods will drop a moon on you before they allow you to retain your current hegemony."
"Meaningless, eh?" Vatnir chuckles quietly.

"Whatever do you mean?"

The other gathered spirits restlessly shift behind you.
"What reason could I have for doing that? How could I trick this court entire?"

"You're suggesting the fragments of her souls are at odds?"

Her eyes close. Her hands clench.

"An interesting hypothesis, and in keeping with the evidence."

Her grin seems almost hungry.
"When we first met, you offered me a relic. You claimed it could change a person's identity."
"You're clearly educated. Intelligent. You expect us to believe otherwise?"
[Remove your mask.]
"You don't find it curious that only the accuser and the accused have form here? "
"This place is formed of trauma - the trauma of an experienced torturer torturing herself."
"Ydwin?"
A gasp echoes through the room as you mime removing the inquisitor's mask from your face. The accused stares up at you in wide-eyed horror.
The scene shimmers and breaks apart, dissolving into a single pulsing mote of essence.
"Then how do you know that wasn't an impostor, someone else taking on my face?"
"Is my upbringing in question? 'Tis hardly evidence of anything!"
"A swabby don't need no formal learning to spin a right fancy lie."
"Why would someone take on the appearance of an accused heretic?"
"I can't imagine. But I'm not the one making accusations."
The accused elf shudders against her shackles, and the other inquisitors hiss. A rising murmur builds among the witnesses.
"Enough with this madness!"

"I doubt she will be capable of understanding in her current state."

She taps two fingers against her lips.
"Give it a try."
"Leave it to me, then."
The animancer nods.
"Rymrgand's influence - or perhaps the nature of this place - has fragmented your soul."
The accused elf shudders against her shackles, and the other inquisitors hiss. A rising murmur builds among the witnesses.
"Some trauma, likely related to your lived experiences, has widened this division. The fragments no longer recognize one another as sharing the same source."
"I can help you escape this place."
"You are not whole, but you can be restored."
"You don't have to keep putting yourself through this."
The accused's face falls, and you see tears fall from her cheeks.
"The inquisitor has been turned!"
"Capture her! She shall pay for her sins!"
The scene shimmers and breaks apart around you, leaving behind a pulsing fragment of essence.
"No crime? Her perfidy is legendary!"
The gathered apparitions exchange confounded glances. Quiet muttering rises among the witnesses. The accused's eyes search your own.
"What do you mean? Then who is 'us?' Who are we?"
"You're a prisoner. And I'm here to set you free."
"You're dead. I'm alive."
"I've come to end this place forever."
"I need your help, and I can't get it while you're answering these questions."
She nods as the other figures begin to shimmer.
"I appreciate that. I hope this helps you."
Strands of essence coalesce before you into a single shining mote.
She recoils, and the other figures bristle.
She recoils, and the other figures bristle.
"And yet, look at yourself."
"Do what you must, then, and we shall see what comes of it."
She sighs, and the breath seems to draw the chamber's essence up to you, pulling it together into a single hard mote of energy.
She sighs, and the breath seems to draw the chamber's essence up to you, pulling it together into a single hard mote of energy.
[Attack] "Enough of this sham!"
The other witnesses step away from you as the masked inquisitors turn their eyes towards your outburst.
"The intruders turn arms against this body! Destroy them!"
